name: Wax Begonia
climate: Wax Begonias thrive in warm, humid climates and are not frost-tolerant.
These plants are best suited for USDA hardiness zones 10 and 11.
In cooler climates, they are often grown as annuals or indoor plants.
They prefer a consistent, mild climate without extreme temperature fluctuations.
sunlight: Wax Begonias do best in partial to full shade in hotter climates.
They can tolerate more sunlight in cooler, northern areas.
Direct, harsh sunlight can scorch their leaves, especially in the afternoon.
Providing dappled shade can help protect them from intense sunlight.
watering: Water Wax Begonias consistently, keeping the soil evenly moist.
Avoid overwatering as it can lead to root rot and other issues.
During hot, dry periods, increase watering frequency as needed.
Let the top inch of soil dry out between waterings to prevent sogginess.
soil: Wax Begonias prefer well-draining, fertile soils rich in organic matter.
A good mix can include peat, perlite, and potting soil for drainage.
Soil pH should be slightly acidic to neutral, ideally between 5.5 and 6.5.
In containers, use a good quality potting mix to ensure proper aeration.
toxic: Wax Begonias are mildly toxic to pets when ingested, causing vomiting.
They contain compounds that can cause irritation in the mouth and throat.
extra_care_tip: To encourage bushier growth, pinch back the stems regularly.
Remove spent blooms to promote new flower production and vitality.
